localizedDescriptions.en: An order for a medication, vaccine, nutritional product or other therapeutic item for an identified individual.
Details of the requested order.
Name of the medication, vaccine or other therapeutic/prescribable item being ordered.

annotations.comment: Depending on the prescribing context this field could be used for either generic- or product-based prescribing. This data field can be used to record tightly bound orders of different medications when they are prescribed as a single pack. It is strongly recommended that the 'Medication item' be coded with a terminology capable of triggering decision support, where possible. The extent of coding may vary from the simple name of the medication item through to structured details about the actual medication pack to be used. Free text entry should only be used if there is no appropriate terminology available.

localizedDescriptions.en: Details about a medication or component of a medication, including strength, form and details of any specific constituents.
The name of the medication or medication component.

annotations.comment: For example: 'Zinacef 750 mg powder' or 'cefuroxim'. This item should be coded if possible, using for example, RxNorm, DM+D, Australian Medicines Terminology or FEST. Usage of this element will vary according to context of use. This element may be omitted where the name of the medication is recorded in the parent INSTRUCTION or ACTION archetype, and this archetype is only used to record that the form must be or was 'liquid'.

localizedDescriptions.en: The formulation or presentation of the medication or medication component.

annotations.comment: For example: 'tablet', 'capsule', 'cream', 'infusion fluid' or 'inhalation powder'. Coding of the form with a terminology is preferred, where possible. Medicines catalogues may differentiate between administrable form 'solution for injection' and product form 'powder for solution for injection'. The recorded form will depend on the exact context of use but administrable form is likely to be used in most instances.

localizedDescriptions.en: The identifier assigned to the origin of the dose itself.
The identifier assigned to the origin of the dose itself.
The identifier assigned to the origin of the dose itself.
The identifier assigned to the origin of the dose itself.
The identifier assigned to the origin of the dose itself.
The identifier assigned to the origin of the dose itself.
Details about a medication or component of a medication, including strength, form and details of any specific constituents.
The name of the medication or medication component.

annotations.comment: For example: 'Zinacef 750 mg powder' or 'cefuroxim'. This item should be coded if possible, using for example, RxNorm, DM+D, Australian Medicines Terminology or FEST. Usage of this element will vary according to context of use. This element may be omitted where the name of the medication is recorded in the parent INSTRUCTION or ACTION archetype, and this archetype is only used to record that the form must be or was 'liquid'.

localizedDescriptions.en: The strength of the medication or medication component, expressed as a ratio.

annotations.comment: In some cases, as for liquid or semisolid medications, the denominator of the strength ratio is a physical quantity, for example 2 mg/5 ml. In some of these cases the denominator also reflects the actual volume of the component: 5 ml in the previous example. In this case the 'Strength (concentration)' would be 0.4 mg/ml. In other cases, where the strength involves a denominator which is not a physical quantity, for example 4 mg/tablet, the denominator is expressed as a unitary value '1' with a unit of 'tablet'. This arrangement was chosen to align with the approach adopted by the ISO IDMP standard for medication catalogues. If the 'Strength (concentration)' element is used, this cluster becomes redundant.

localizedDescriptions.en: The numerator of the strength fraction.

annotations.comment: For example: For a presentation strength of '300 µg/0.3 ml', the strength numerator is '300 µg'. For a presentation strength of '100 mg/tablet', the strength numerator value is '100 mg'.

localizedDescriptions.en: The denominator of the strength fraction.

annotations.comment: For example: For a presentation strength of '300 µg/0.3 ml', the strength denominator value is '0.3 ml'. For a presentation strength of '100 mg/tablet', the strength denominator value is '1 tablet'.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description of the medication or medication component where it is not possible to describe this fully using structured elements.
The route by which the ordered item is to be administered into the subject's body.

annotations.comment:
For example: 'oral', 'intravenous', or 'topical'.
Coding of the route with a terminology is preferred, where possible. Multiple potential routes may be specified.

localizedDescriptions.en: Complete narrative description about how the ordered item is to be used.

annotations.comment: This narrative should normally subsume data captured in 'Dose amount', 'Dose timing' and any additional instructions for use. Where the medication dose directions are fully carried by the structured, computable dose directions, this element should carry the narrative equivalent, generally auto-generated. If it is not possible to represent the intended 'Dose direction' fully in computable form, partial representation is not recommended, and the directions should be only recorded in narrative form using this data element.

localizedDescriptions.en: Structured details of a single therapeutic direction for an ordered item, such as a medication or blood transfusion order.
The length of time for which this direction should be applied.

annotations.comment: For example: 'for 7 days','Indefinite'. An example of a set of multiple directions, with varying durations might be ... '1 tablet daily for 3 days, 2 tablets daily for 4 days, then 3 tablets Indefinite'.

localizedDescriptions.en: The date and optional time to commence the administration.
The date and optional time when it is planned to cease the administration.
Structured details of a single therapeutic direction for an ordered item, such as a medication or blood transfusion order.
The intended position of this direction within the overall sequence of directions.

annotations.comment:
For example: ''1' '2', '3'.
Where multiple dosage directions are expressed, the 'Direction sequence' makes the order in which they should be executed explicit. For example: (1) 1 tab daily for 3 days, (2) 1 tab twice daily for 4 days, (3) 1 tablet for 7 days.

localizedDescriptions.en: The combination of a medication amount and administration timing for a single day, in the context of a medication order or medication management.

annotations.comment: For example: '2 tablets at 6pm' or '20 mg three times per day'. Please note: this cluster allows multiple occurrences to enable representation of a complete set of dose patterns for a single dose direction.

localizedDescriptions.en: The amount of medication administered at one time.

annotations.comment: For example: 1 mg, 1.5 ml, 0.125 g; or 1-2 ml, 12.5-20.5 mg.

localizedDescriptions.en: The amount of medication administered at one time.
The amount of medication administered at one time.
Structured information about the intended timing of a therapeutic or diagnostic activity within any 24 hour period.
The frequency as number of times per time period that the activity is to take place.

annotations.comment: For example: "4 times per day" or "3 to 4 times per hour".

localizedDescriptions.en: The frequency as number of times per time period that the activity is to take place.
The frequency as number of times per time period that the activity is to take place.
The time interval or minimum and maximum range of an interval between each scheduled activity.

annotations.comment: For example: "Every 4 hours" or "Every 4 to 6 hours".

localizedDescriptions.en: A specific time or interval of time when the activity should occur.
Text description of the daily timing. This element is intended to allow implementers to use the structures for different timings without necessarily specifying the timings in a structured way.

annotations.comment: For example: "Take morning and evening".

localizedDescriptions.en: The rate at which the medication, such as an infusion, is to be administered.

annotations.comment: For example: '200 ml/h'. Use the text data type to record non- or semi-quantifiable instructions.

localizedDescriptions.en: The period of time over which a single dose of the medication or vaccine should be administered.

annotations.comment: For example: 'Administer over 10 minutes'.

localizedDescriptions.en: The period of time over which a single dose of the medication or vaccine should be administered.
The period of time over which a single dose of the medication or vaccine should be administered.
The length of time for which this direction should be applied.

annotations.comment: For example: 'for 7 days','Indefinite'. An example of a set of multiple directions, with varying durations might be ... '1 tablet daily for 3 days, 2 tablets daily for 4 days, then 3 tablets Indefinite'.

localizedDescriptions.en: The length of time for which this direction should be applied.
The direction should be continued indefinitely.
The length of time for which this direction should be applied.
Structured information about the intended timing pattern for a therapeutic or diagnostic activity occurring over days, weeks, months or years.
The interval between repetitions of the activity.

annotations.comment: For example: 'Every 3 weeks'. If necessary, this element can be used to explicity specify that an activity is to take place every single day, by setting it to "1 day".

localizedDescriptions.en: The number of days per time period on which the activity takes place.

annotations.comment: For example: '3 days per week', '2-4 days per month'. Specific details about the timing within each 24 hour period is specified within the CLUSTER.timing_daily archetype.

localizedDescriptions.en: The number of days per time period on which the activity takes place.
The number of days per time period on which the activity takes place.
The activity should take place on a specific day of the week.

annotations.comment: For example: 'On Monday, Wednesday and Friday'.

localizedDescriptions.en: The activity should take place on Monday.
The activity should take place on Tuesday.
The activity should take place on Wednesday.
The activity should take place on Thursday.
The activity should take place on Friday.
The activity should take place on Saturday.
The activity should take place on Sunday.
Text description of the timing.

annotations.comment: For example: 'Use for one week, then stop for two weeks, then repeat'. This element is intended to allow implementers to use the structures for daily timings without necessarily specifying the non-daily timings in a structured way.

localizedDescriptions.en: Details of conditions on which determine the dose amount or administration rate.
Details of the condition and associated dose amount or administration rate.
The value which is required for the associated dose amount or administration to be applied.
The dose amount to be administered if the condition applies.
An additional instruction on how to use or store the ordered item.

annotations.comment: For example: precautions as 'take with food', 'Avoid grapefruit', 'Dissolve in water', 'store in a cool, dry place'. This data element allows multiple occurrences and should be coded with a reference terminology, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: Advice to future prescribers/dispensers about the ongoing, long term order.

annotations.comment: For example: 'don't allow brand substitution' or advice regarding using a specific brand to avoid fillers that cause reactions.

annotations.comment: For example: 'Stop after symptoms disappear''.

localizedDescriptions.en: Overall summary of the medication order.
The overall status of this order.
This is a medication that has previously been issued, dispensed or administered but has now been discontinued.
Actions resulting from the order are to be temporarily halted, but are expected to continue later. May also be called 'on-hold'.
Additional narrative about the medication order not captured in other fields.
